user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_MD5_update:
```c
void
MHD_MD5_update (struct Md5Ctx *ctx,
                const uint8_t *data,
                size_t length)
{
  unsigned int bytes_have; /**< Number of bytes in the context buffer */

  mhd_assert ((data != NULL) || (length == 0));

#ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  if (0 == length)
    return; /* Shortcut, do nothing */
#endif /* MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */

  /* Note: (count & (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE-1))
           equals (count % MD5_BLOCK_SIZE) for this block size. */
  bytes_have = (unsigned int) (ctx->count & (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - 1));
  ctx->count += length;

  if (0 != bytes_have)
  {
    unsigned int bytes_left = MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - bytes_have;
    if (length >= bytes_left)
    {     /* Combine new data with data in the buffer and
             process the full block. */
      memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have,
              data,
              bytes_left);
      data += bytes_left;
      length -= bytes_left;
      md5_transform (ctx->H, ctx->buffer);
      bytes_have = 0;
    }
  }

  while (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE <= length)
  {   /* Process any full blocks of new data directly,
         without copying to the buffer. */
    md5_transform (ctx->H, data);
    data += MD5_BLOCK_SIZE;
    length -= MD5_BLOCK_SIZE;
  }

  if (0 != length)
  {   /* Copy incomplete block of new data (if any)
         to the buffer. */
    memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have, data, length);
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Only the calls to the string.h function memcpy are potentially relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 and therefore need investigation. Other fragments do not require investigation under this rule because:
- The function asserts (data != NULL) || (length == 0), and an early return is taken when length == 0 (in non-small-code builds), ensuring memcpy is not invoked with a NULL data pointer when a non-zero copy size would be used.
- The code computes bytes_have = ctx->count & (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - 1) and uses bytes_left = MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - bytes_have together with explicit checks (length >= bytes_left) and the subsequent while loop (while (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE <= length)) to ensure that the sizes passed to memcpy are bounded by MD5_BLOCK_SIZE and that full-block processing is handled separately. These length checks and arithmetic guard against passing lengths larger than a single block to memcpy.
- Calls to md5_transform are not part of <string.h> and thus are out of scope for Rule 21.17.
Consequently, only the memcpy invocations should be investigated further (e.g. to confirm the actual size of ctx->buffer, alignment/overlap constraints, and that data points to at least the requested number of bytes).
